summary: This is an internal email from July 22, 2019, within the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York, providing a detailed rundown of recent interviews and the status of various employees, associates, and victims in the Jeffrey Epstein investigation. It outlines allegations of sexual abuse, recruitment of minors, and the roles of Epstein's staff.

persons.name: Geoffrey Berman
persons.context: Recipient of the email update on the Epstein investigation from the Southern District of New York team.

persons.name: Groff
persons.context: An employee/associate who was given a reverse proffer and is considering cooperating with the investigation.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.role: Friend / former girlfriend alleged to be involved in recruiting
persons.context: Her attorneys met with the team; she is assessing whether to proffer. Allegedly involved in recruiting girls for Epstein.

persons.name: Megan Dorschel Dettling
persons.context: Gave Epstein massages twice in the early 2000s at the Florida estate and has reservations about testifying.

persons.name: Tatum Miller
persons.context: Recruited at age 13 or 14, gave numerous massages to Epstein over about three years, and estimates she brought as many as one hundred underage girls to Epstein's house. Was represented by an attorney paid by Epstein during the Florida investigation.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central figure in the investigation, accused of sexual abuse of minors, with details about his daily massage routines, interactions with victims, and statements to staff.

connections.description: Described as a friend/former girlfriend alleged to be involved in recruiting girls for Epstein.
Miller was recruited as a minor and gave numerous massages to Epstein; she also recruited many other underage girls for him.
Employee-3 worked as Epstein's assistant from late 2004 to early 2006, scheduling massages and appointments, and later had sexual encounters with him.
The house manager worked for Epstein from the 90s through 2002, noting changes in Epstein's behavior and being told by Epstein to 'keep your mouth shut' upon leaving.

events.title: Employee-3 hired by Epstein
events.description: Epstein offered Employee-3 a job as an assistant around December 2004, which she accepted.

events.title: New York victim recruitment
events.description: A victim (New York Victim 1) was recruited at age 14 by an unidentified woman outside her school on the Upper East Side and provided nude massages to Epstein for about a year.

events.title: Florida victim abuse
events.description: A Florida victim was abused once in 2002 at the Florida estate during a massage and recruited another minor girl for Epstein.

events.title: Abuse of victim post-18
events.description: A victim met Epstein at age 17 in 2007; after turning 18, she began giving him massages involving abuse, and Epstein had intercourse with her multiple times, with the first few being nonconsensual.

events.title: Epstein arranges marriage
events.description: Epstein paid $10,000 for a victim to marry a girl so she could stay in the U.S.; they were married for about four years and divorced in 2017.

events.title: Investigation updates and proffers
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office provides a rundown of recent interviews with employees, associates, and victims, and notes ongoing proffer discussions with several individuals.

keyFacts: Epstein expected two massages daily: one in the morning and one in the afternoon, coordinated by staff in Palm Beach and New York.
Employee-3 described two groups of girls giving massages: professional masseuses for friends, and young, non-professional girls (often minors) only for Epstein.

Tatum Miller, recruited at age 13 or 14, estimates she brought as many as one hundred underage girls to Epstein's house for massages and was represented by an Epstein-paid attorney during the Florida investigation.
Epstein told a former house manager that 'these girls only care about money' and, upon the manager's departure, said 'I hope you keep your mouth shut.'
In 2013, Epstein paid $10,000 for a victim to marry a girl to help her stay in the U.S.; they divorced in 2017.
